Sigh.

Craig

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Richard Heyworth
Sent: Wednesday, May 26, 2010 11:09 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Moderator please


The pics are fantastic !!!! Did you take them?

Thanks

Rich






This message contains information which may be confidential and privileged.
Unless you are the intended addressee (or authorized to receive for the
intended addressee), you may not use, copy or disclose to anyone the message
or any information contained in the message. If you have received the
message in error, please advise the sender by reply and delete the message.
To the extent contractual confidentiality obligations exist, this message
and all information transmitted with it are designated "Confidential".







To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
From: jggilbert@...
Date: Wed, 26 May 2010 00:46:23 +0000
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Moderator please







Mr. nicemaletrust posts hundreds of messages, but they get stopped before
they hit the list, he gets deleted and he rejoins under a new but similar
user name. I've come to admire "his" persistence, although he's probably a
boiler room somewhere rather than an individual.

I'm afraid that Gordon may be waving his cane and yelling at the kids to
stay off his lawn before long...

I had a chance to look at a very interesting tsuba recently. It's a typical
bird in the plum tree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it wasn't
completed. The design is scribed into the plate and all of the roughing out
was done with a chisel. Even the outline of the rim is chiseled in with
multiple cuts from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was used while
cutting the rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chisel.

A couple of sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the rest is
still rough. It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down too
thin to be finished properly and the piece was abandoned. The color of the
guard isn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the build
up on the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an Edo
piece.

I recently spent two weeks shooting in Baja Sur, Mexico. A great place,
other than the developed Cabo area on the southern tip.

A few wildlife photos from both the Pacific and Gulf sides:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157623839030000/

Jim

www.jimgilbertphoto.com

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
>
> and I think julius_lopez82@... asked a legit question on Ichimonji ?
>
> I had a quick check and Jim's deleted someone named nicemaletrust who
> keeps coming back bit thats all I see.
>
> cheers
>
> Rich

This message contains information which may be confidential and privileged. Unless you are the intended addressee (or authorized to receive for the intended addressee), you may not use, copy or disclose to anyone the message or any information contained in the message. To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
From: jggilbert@...
Date: Wed, 26 May 2010 00:46:23 +0000
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Moderator please







Mr. nicemaletrust posts hundreds of messages, but they get stopped before they hit the list, he gets deleted and he rejoins under a new but similar user name. I've come to admire "his" persistence, although he's probably a boiler room somewhere rather than an individual.

I'm afraid that Gordon may be waving his cane and yelling at the kids to stay off his lawn before long...

I had a chance to look at a very interesting tsuba recently. It's a typical bird in the plum tree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it wasn't completed. The design is scribed into the plate and all of the roughing out was done with a chisel. Even the outline of the rim is chiseled in with multiple cuts from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was used while cutting the rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chisel.

A couple of sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the rest is still rough. It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down too thin to be finished properly and the piece was abandoned. The color of the guard isn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the build up on the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an Edo piece.

I recently spent two weeks shooting in Baja Sur, Mexico. A great place, other than the developed Cabo area on the southern tip.

A few wildlife photos from both the Pacific and Gulf sides:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157623839030000/

Jim

www.jimgilbertphoto.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Moderator please
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, It s really very nice to hear from you.  I m sure we have all missed your worthy contributions to your list.  I m a bit concerned to read of your
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

It's really very nice to hear from you. I'm sure we have all missed your worthy contributions to "your" list. I'm a bit concerned to read of your shooting - did you mean with a camera??!!! With your bird-loving pursuits I wonderd if your shooting was blasting feathers off a delicious table bird... Do please tell...

Bestests,
Barry Thomas.
----- Original Message -----
From: yamaimojg
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, May 26, 2010 10:23 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Moderator please


Mr. nicemaletrust posts hundreds of messages, but they get stopped before they hit the list, he gets deleted and he rejoins under a new but similar user name. I've come to admire "his" persistence, although he's probably a boiler room somewhere rather than an individual.

I'm afraid that Gordon may be waving his cane and yelling at the kids to stay off his lawn before long...

I had a chance to look at a very interesting tsuba recently. It's a typical bird in the plum tree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it wasn't completed. The design is scribed into the plate and all of the roughing out was done with a chisel. Even the outline of the rim is chiseled in with multiple cuts from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was used while cutting the rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chisel.

A couple of sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the rest is still rough. It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down too thin to be finished properly and the piece was abandoned. The color of the guard isn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the build up on the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an Edo piece.

I recently spent two weeks shooting in Baja Sur, Mexico. A great place, other than the developed Cabo area on the southern tip.

A few wildlife photos from both the Pacific and Gulf sides:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/jggilbert/sets/72157623839030000/

Jim

www.jimgilbertphoto.com

Mr. nicemaletrust posts hundreds of messages, but they get stopped before
they hit the list, he gets deleted and he rejoins under a new but similar
user name. I've come to admire "his" persistence, although he's probably a
boiler room somewhere rather than an individual.

I'm afraid that Gordon may be waving his cane and yelling at the kids to
stay off his lawn before long...

I had a chance to look at a very interesting tsuba recently. It's a typical
bird in the plum tree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it wasn't
completed. The design is scribed into the plate and all of the roughing out
was done with a chisel. Even the outline of the rim is chiseled in with
multiple cuts from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was used while
cutting the rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chisel.

A couple of sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the rest is
still rough. It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down too
thin to be finished properly and the piece was abandoned. The color of the
guard isn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the build
up on the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an Edo
piece.

I recently spent two weeks shooting in Baja Sur, Mexico. A great place,
